docinfo.docinfo:doc-heading: PART 34 NOTICES TO PRODUCE AT HEARING [rr 34.1–34.3]

heading.title: PART 34 NOTICES TO PRODUCE AT HEARING [rr 34.1–34.3]

leg:level-vrnt.toc-caption: PART 34 NOTICES TO PRODUCE AT HEARING [rr 34.1–34.3]

entry.emph: Notices to produce at trial — Rules 34.1–34.3

row.entry: This Part governs the procedure for giving a notice to produce to another party and the obligation to produce documents or things in accordance with such notice.

This Part applies to all courts in Schedule 1 of the CP Act, except the Industrial Relations Commission when constituted otherwise than as the Industrial Court (except to the extent to which the Commission orders that the Part is to apply): see r 1.5 and Sch 1.
The Part is based on the former SCR Part 36, DCR Part 28 and LCR Part 23.
Production of specified documents or things ‥ [r 34.1.15]
Related powers to obtain production of documents ‥ [r 34.1.10]
Sufficiency of compliance and sanction for non-compliance ‥ [r 34.1.25]

leg:level-vrnt.toc-caption: [r 34.1] r 34.1 Production on notice (cf SCR Part 36, rule 16; DCR Part 28, rule 18; LCR Part 23, rule 9)

leg:heading.title: Production on notice (cf SCR Part 36, rule 16; DCR Part 28, rule 18; LCR Part 23, rule 9)

p.text: A party may, by notice served on another party, require the other party to produce to the court, or to any examiner:
at any hearing in the proceedings or before any such examiner, or
at any time fixed by the court for the return of subpoenas, or
by leave of the court, at some other specified time,
any specified document or thing.
[subr (1) am Amendment 11 of 2006 r 2 and Sch 1[18], effective 8 December 2006]
The other party must comply with a notice to produce:

by producing the notice or a copy of it, and the document or thing, to the court, or to the examiner authorised to take evidence in the proceeding as permitted by the court, at the date, time and place specified for production, or

by delivering or sending the notice or a copy of it, and the document or thing, to the registrar at the address specified for the purpose in the notice, so that they are received not less than 2 clear days before the date specified in the notice for production.
[subr (2) insrt Amendment 11 of 2006 r 2 and Sch 1[19], effective 8 December 2006]
The approved form is Form 24 : Notice to produce to court.

level.toc-caption: [34.1.10] Related powers to obtain production of documents

p.text: Legislation cited in [34.1.10] below. LawNow subscribers click through for daily updates and historical versions.
(NSW) Civil Procedure Act 2005 CPA s 50, CPA s 68.
(NSW) Evidence Act 1995 s 36.
(NSW) Uniform Civil Procedure Rules 2005 UCPR Pt 33, UCPR 17.5(4).

heading.title: Related powers to obtain production of documents

p.text: Related provisions dealing with production of documents include:
deemed notice to produce discovered documents at trial: UCPR 17.5(4) .

level.toc-caption: [34.1.15] Production of specified documents or things

heading.title: Production of specified documents or things

p.text: This rule permits notice to produce “specified” things or documents. It does not permit an order in the nature of the discovery: Straker v Reynolds (1889) 22 QBD 262 ; Elder v Carter (1890) 25 QBD 194 ; O'Shea v Wood [1891] P 237 at 286; Re Smith [1891] 1 Ch 323 ; Hedges v Burchell (1913) 17 CLR 327; 20 ALR 4 ; Australian Consolidated Press Ltd v Bond (1982) 61 FLR 91 : as to the requirements of “specificity” see further [21.10.15] and [33.4.20] , [33.4.25] .
Legislation cited in [34.1.17] below. LawNow subscribers click through for daily updates and historical versions.
(NSW) Uniform Civil Procedure Rules 2005 UCPR 21.2.

A notice to produce may be set aside in the same way as a subpoena: see [21.10.25] and [33.4.10] – [34.4.65] . In particular, a notice to produce documents at the trial cannot be used as a means of obtaining further and better discovery, and especially not where orders have previously been made under UCPR 21.2 defining the classes of documents required for discovery: Tony Azzi AutomobilesPty Ltd v Volvo Car Australia Pty Ltd [2006] NSWSC 283; BC200602227 at [10]–[15] .
Legislation cited in [34.1.20] below. LawNow subscribers click through for daily updates and historical versions.
(CTH) Corporations Act 2001 Pt 5.9.

The power conferred by this rule in relation to the production of documents to an examiner is more limited than the general subpoena power. It is confined to the production of documents that are potentially relevant to the examination of a particular person: Re BPTC Ltd (in liq) (No 2) (1992) 29 NSWLR 713; 8 ACSR 533 ; Re BPTC Ltd (in liq) (No 3) (1993) 29 NSWLR 708; 11 ACLC 365 at 368 ; Re BPTC Ltd (in liq) (No 5) (1993) 10 ACSR 756; 11 ACLC 734 ; Australian Development Corp Pty Ltd v White Constructions (ACT) Pty Ltd (NSWSC, Giles J, 3 December 1993, unreported, BC9302278) : see further, in relation to examination under Pt 5.9 of the Corporations Act [15,785.5]–[15,785.30] .

level.toc-caption: [34.1.25] Sufficiency of compliance and sanction for non-compliance

p.text: Legislation cited in [34.1.25] below. LawNow subscribers click through for daily updates and historical versions.
(NSW) Uniform Civil Procedure Rules 2005 UCPR r 33.12, UCPR r 34.2(1).
(NSW) Civil Procedure Act 2005 CPA s 61, CPA s 68.

heading.title: Sufficiency of compliance and sanction for non-compliance

p.text: A party served with a notice to produce may be subject to examination, to at least the same extent as a person who answers a subpoena, about the sufficiency of their compliance: see [33.6.15] and Pyoja Pty Ltd v 284 Bronte Road Developments Pty Ltd [2006] NSWSC 831; BC200606373 at [28]–[32] . Although UCPR r 34.2(1) conditionally mandates compliance with a Notice to Produce, there is no provision determining that non-compliance constitutes contempt: contrast UCPR r 33.12 . However the Court (including a Registrar in the Supreme Court: Pyoja Pty Ltd v 284 Bronte Road Developments Pty Ltd [2006] NSWSC 831; BC200606373 at [26] ; or a Judicial Registrar in the District Court) may order production under CPA s 68 or give appropriate directions under CPA s 61 . Orders or directions made under those provisions may indirectly enliven the court’s contempt powers.

leg:level-vrnt.toc-caption: [r 34.2] r 34.2 Production under notice to produce at trial (cf SCR Part 36, rule 16; DCR Part 28, rule 18; LCR Part 23, rule 9)

leg:heading.title: Production under notice to produce at trial (cf SCR Part 36, rule 16; DCR Part 28, rule 18; LCR Part 23, rule 9)

p.text: Unless the court orders otherwise, the other party must produce the document or thing in accordance with the notice to produce, without the need for any subpoena for production, if the document or thing is in his or her possession.
[subr (2) rep Amendment 11 of 2006 r 2 and Sch 1[20], effective 8 December 2006]
Except by leave of the court, a party may not search for, or inspect, any document or thing that has been produced by another party under this rule but not admitted into evidence.

The present rule imposes an obligation to comply with the notice. The nature of that obligation, and the corresponding entitlement to have the court “otherwise order”, is similar to those which apply in relation to subpoenas: Bailey v Beagle Management Pty Ltd (2001) 105 FCR 136; 182 ALR 264; [2001] FCA 60; BC200100211 . In these respects the rule effectively removes the old limitations on notices to produce. It is no longer true to say that there is no compulsion to produce the documents, nor that its purpose is merely to permit the use of secondary evidence if the documents sought are not produced in response to the notice: CCOM Pty Ltd v Jiejing Pty Ltd (1992) 37 FCR 1; 109 ALR 673 ; Dwyer v Collins (1852) 7 Exch 639; 155 ER 1104 ; Morgan v Babcock and Wilcox Ltd (1929) 43 CLR 163 at 172; 35 ALR 313; 3 ALJR 234 ; Ewart v Royds (1955) 72 WN (NSW) 58 at 59.
Legislation cited in [34.2.10] below. LawNow subscribers click through for daily updates and historical versions.
(NSW) Uniform Civil Procedure Rules 2005 r 21.5.
See the annotations to r 21.5 .

The discretion to otherwise order will necessarily be influenced by the content of the notice and the apparent relevance of the material sought to the proceedings in the court. Thus it may be appropriate for the court to “otherwise order” in circumstances when the Notice to Produce is served upon a party to proceedings which has not entered an appearance and which is challenging the court's jurisdiction: News Corp Ltd v Lenfest Communications Inc (1996) 40 NSWLR 250; 21 ACSR 403; BC9603543 but compare Cigna Insurance Australia Ltd v CSR Ltd (NSWSC, Rolfe J, 10 November 1995, unreported, BC9501624).

leg:level-vrnt.toc-caption: [r 34.3] r 34.3 Costs and expenses of compliance (cf rule 33.11)

leg:heading.title: Costs and expenses of compliance (cf rule 33.11)

p.text: The court may order the party requiring production to pay the amount of any reasonable loss or expense incurred by the party required to produce in complying with a notice to produce.
If an order is made under subrule (1), the court must fix the amount or direct that it be fixed in accordance with the court’s usual procedure in relation to costs.
[r 34.3 insrt Gaz 87 of 6 July 2007 r 2 and Sch 1[7], effective 6 July 2007]

level.toc-caption: [34.3.5] Costs and expenses of compliance with notice of motion

p.text: Legislation cited in [34.3.5] below. LawNow subscribers click through for daily updates and historical versions.
(NSW) Uniform Civil Procedure Rules 2005 r 42.33.

heading.title: Costs and expenses of compliance with notice of motion

p.text: The court has power to order a party to pay the costs and expenses of compliance with a notice to produce. (As to what may fall within the concept of “reasonable loss or expense” see [33.11.5] .) The parties must attempt to agree on the amount of costs and expenses that are payable for compliance before seeking an order for the payment of those costs and expenses: see UCPR r 42.33 .
